<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/a-changed-wework-goes-public-via-spac?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
If At First You Don't Succeed...SPAC
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/a-changed-wework-goes-public-via-spac?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A sign on a WeWork office in Miami" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1f691e2b1335fad106ff3a3a1ee494ef4ec28979-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>JP Yim/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What a long, strange trip it’s been. Just over two years after its first attempt to IPO shattered into a million documentaries, WeWork <a href="https://apnews.com/article/business-30850530968ca195239e9e25021c761c?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">went public</a> yesterday via SPAC. This deal valued the company at $9 billion; WeWork was worth $47 billion in 2019.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">WeWork, but make it mini</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">These days, WeWork’s aspiration is less “elevate the world’s consciousness,” as its mission stated in 2019, and more “use us so your employees don’t go crazy working from home.” The shared-office company feels like it’s <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/wework-set-to-go-public-via-spac-deal-two-years-after-failed-ipo-11634808600?mod=hp_lead_pos3" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">well positioned</a> to offer space to companies with globe-spanning workforces operating on a more flexible schedule.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Another bullish trend for WeWork: Entrepreneurship is </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/19/business/startup-business-creation-pandemic.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">booming</a></span><span>. Applications for new businesses in 2020 grew 24% year over year to the most on record. As Morning Brew can attest, growing startups are excellent potential clients for WeWork offices.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company is still digging out of a deep financial hole. WeWork lost more than $6 billion in the 18 months leading up to this summer as the pandemic throttled office work. And occupancy rates were just 55% as of June 1. To put the company in a position to be profitable next year, CEO Sandeep Mathrani has been on a cost-cutting spree, axing thousands of jobs and renegotiating leases.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">And what about Adam Neumann?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">He’s not sorry for party rocking. The WeWork cofounder and former CEO, whose marketing savvy was matched only by his proclivity for hosting ragers, resigned in disgrace in 2019 after financial documents showed seriously sketchy corporate governance practices at the company, among many other red flags.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But he's doing just fine. Neumann still has 11% voting power at WeWork, and after his share sales, his stock in the new company is <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-21/what-is-adam-neumann-s-net-worth-wework-founder-has-2-3-billion-fortune?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">worth $722 million</a>, according to Bloomberg. In fact, Neumann’s name appears in the SPAC filing 197 times.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So it wasn’t surprising to see Neumann partying with cofounder Miguel McKelvey and other early WeWork employees in Manhattan yesterday. He said he had absorbed “hard lessons” from the fiasco, but he’s “excited for the future.”—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FED
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/senior-fed-officials-banned-from-owning-individual-stocks-and-bonds-in-new-policy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Fed Leaders Can No Longer HODL
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/senior-fed-officials-banned-from-owning-individual-stocks-and-bonds-in-new-policy?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A shoulders-up photo of Fed Chair Jerome Powell looking off into the distance" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/f87c5338c52518030d37448a3e4d66e036131908-6000x4000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Sarah Silbiger/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, well, well, looks like senior officials at the Federal Reserve will have to dump all their AMC shares. Facing backlash over members’ stock trading during the pandemic, the Fed <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/21/fed-to-ban-policymakers-from-owning-individual-stocks-restrict-trading-following-controversy.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> a new set of rules re: officials’ investing habits yesterday that are stricter than a high school band trip’s hotel policy.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The 12 reserve bank presidents and seven governors on the central bank’s board will be banned from owning individual stocks and bonds. They will only be allowed to invest in securities like mutual funds.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If Fed officials want to trade, they’ll need to give a 45-day notice before buying or selling and must hold onto their purchase for at least one year. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quick backstory:</strong> Documents <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/16/federal-reserve-announces-ethics-investigation-regional-bank-officials-trading?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> last month showed some regional Fed presidents held thousands of dollars in individual stocks like Pfizer and Chevron, two presidents even resigned shortly after the news broke. Their trading activity was all above board, but it’s not a great look since these folks play a huge role in shaping the US economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> It’s likely not a coincidence that the crackdown comes at the same time that Fed Chair Jerome Powell, who ordered the initial ethics investigation, waits for Biden’s invite to serve a second term, especially since Powell has <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-imposes-new-restrictions-on-officials-investment-activities-11634839207?mod=hp_lead_pos1" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">faced criticism</a> from some Democratic lawmakers.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/worldcoin-would-like-you-to-gaze-upon-this-orb-and-receive-free-crypto?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Gaze Into Orb, Get Crypto
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/21/worldcoin-would-like-you-to-gaze-upon-this-orb-and-receive-free-crypto?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A chrome orb with an iris scanner on it sitting atop a pillar to look like a crystal ball" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c963a8d85bbdff05411338707403588e62fb7e99-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Ah, the classic Econ 101 concepts: the invisible hand, the tragedy of the commons, the one about how if you stare into an orb you’ll receive free cryptocurrency.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Worldcoin, a project cofounded by former Y Combinator president Sam Altman, is literally offering cryptocurrency (its own) in exchange for staring into a chrome orb that scans your irises. Yesterday it announced it’s <a href="https://www.coindesk.com/business/2021/10/21/worldcoin-now-valued-at-1b-has-grand-plans-to-get-you-to-gaze-into-the-orb/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised $25 million</a>, bringing its value to $1 billion. The concept is kind of a <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/21/sam-altmans-worldcoin-wants-to-scan-your-eyes-in-exchange-for-crypto.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crypto-attempt at universal basic income</a>, and the eye-scanning orbs are—according to Worldcoin—a way to ensure that nobody gets multiple payouts.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The use of biometric data has, of course, raised lots of privacy concerns. Critics <a href="https://www.vox.com/recode/22557715/worldcoin-sam-altman-cryptocurency-orb-eye-scanning-iris-biometrics-privacy-concern?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">don’t buy into Worldcoin’s security claims</a>, and others say the concept seems to require central control over the cryptocurrency—which doesn’t exactly jibe with blockchain decentralization principles. Worldcoin says it will never sell personal data (though it is currently <a href="https://www.wired.co.uk/article/worldcoin-cryptocurrency-sam-altman?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">storing it</a> in order to, according to the company, improve fraud-detection algorithms).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not everyone is so skeptical, however. Worldcoin says 130,000 people have already gazed into the orb. The company plans to ramp up orb production from 30 to 4,000 per month beginning in November.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just kidding. Like everyone else, we can’t predict the future. <img alt="Austin Li, China's " Lipstick King"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/de98386812efbf6008e76f8533423e6552f5f088-1024x682.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Austin Li, known as China’s “King of Lipstick,” sold <a href="https://twitter.com/ruima/status/1451193168603463683?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$1.65 billion worth of goods</a> during a 12 hour, 26 minute livestream yesterday on the Taobao Live platform, according to tech analyst Rui Ma. It was part of a promotion for Alibaba’s upcoming Singles’ Day, the largest shopping event in the world.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> “It’s a right load of codswallop.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A spokesperson for the Maine CDC dismissed an unsubstantiated claim made by Zha Liyou, the Chinese consul general in Kolkata, India, who—along with <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/china-linked-disinformation-campaign-blames-covid-maine-lobsters-rcna3236?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hundreds of other Twitter accounts</a>—alleged that the Covid-19 pandemic originated from thawed Maine lobsters imported to China from the US.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The metaphysics of the hangover. (<a href="https://hedgehogreview.com/issues/the-meaning-of-cities/articles/the-metaphysics-of-the-hangover?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Hedgehog Review</a>)</p>

<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nora and Scott from <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/MYLxUCXE?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Morning Brew’s <em>Business Casual</em></a> sat down with journalist Stacey Vanek Smith, co-host of NPR’s <em>The Indicator from Planet Money</em>, to discuss her new book, <em>Machiavelli for Women</em>, which takes a fun and empowering approach to shattering the glass ceiling.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">She applies Machiavelli’s <em>The Prince</em>—you know, the brutish, 16th century political instruction guide for Italian princes to gain and keep power—to the status of 21st century women in the workforce. Turns out, Machiavelli has some pretty solid ideas about overcoming the obstacles that stand in the way of leadership positions. <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/MYLxUCXE?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Listen to the full episode to learn some actionable tips to win at the workplace.</a></p>
</div>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhat a long, strange trip it’s been. Just over two years after its first attempt to IPO shattered into a million documentaries, WeWork \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/business-30850530968ca195239e9e25021c761c?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewent public\u003c/a\u003e yesterday via SPAC. This deal valued the company at $9 billion; WeWork was worth $47 billion in 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWeWork, but make it mini\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThese days, WeWork’s aspiration is less “elevate the world’s consciousness,” as its mission stated in 2019, and more “use us so your employees don’t go crazy working from home.” The shared-office company feels like it’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/wework-set-to-go-public-via-spac-deal-two-years-after-failed-ipo-11634808600?mod=hp_lead_pos3\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewell positioned\u003c/a\u003e to offer space to companies with globe-spanning workforces operating on a more flexible schedule.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnother bullish trend for WeWork: Entrepreneurship is \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/19/business/startup-business-creation-pandemic.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebooming\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Applications for new businesses in 2020 grew 24% year over year to the most on record. As Morning Brew can attest, growing startups are excellent potential clients for WeWork offices.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe company is still digging out of a deep financial hole. WeWork lost more than $6 billion in the 18 months leading up to this summer as the pandemic throttled office work. And occupancy rates were just 55% as of June 1. To put the company in a position to be profitable next year, CEO Sandeep Mathrani has been on a cost-cutting spree, axing thousands of jobs and renegotiating leases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAnd what about Adam Neumann?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHe’s not sorry for party rocking. The WeWork cofounder and former CEO, whose marketing savvy was matched only by his proclivity for hosting ragers, resigned in disgrace in 2019 after financial documents showed seriously sketchy corporate governance practices at the company, among many other red flags.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut he's doing just fine. Neumann still has 11% voting power at WeWork, and after his share sales, his stock in the new company is \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-21/what-is-adam-neumann-s-net-worth-wework-founder-has-2-3-billion-fortune?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eworth $722 million\u003c/a\u003e, according to Bloomberg. In fact, Neumann’s name appears in the SPAC filing 197 times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo it wasn’t surprising to see Neumann partying with cofounder Miguel McKelvey and other early WeWork employees in Manhattan yesterday. He said he had absorbed “hard lessons” from the fiasco, but he’s “excited for the future.”—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable officials at the Federal Reserve will have to dump all their AMC shares. Facing backlash over members’ stock trading during the pandemic, the Fed \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/21/fed-to-ban-policymakers-from-owning-individual-stocks-restrict-trading-following-controversy.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased\u003c/a\u003e a new set of rules re: officials’ investing habits yesterday that are stricter than a high school band trip’s hotel policy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe 12 reserve bank presidents and seven governors on the central bank’s board will be banned from owning individual stocks and bonds. They will only be allowed to invest in securities like mutual funds.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf Fed officials want to trade, they’ll need to give a 45-day notice before buying or selling and must hold onto their purchase for at least one year. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eQuick backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e Documents \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/16/federal-reserve-announces-ethics-investigation-regional-bank-officials-trading?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased\u003c/a\u003e last month showed some regional Fed presidents held thousands of dollars in individual stocks like Pfizer and Chevron, two presidents even resigned shortly after the news broke. Their trading activity was all above board, but it’s not a great look since these folks play a huge role in shaping the US economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e It’s likely not a coincidence that the crackdown comes at the same time that Fed Chair Jerome Powell, who ordered the initial ethics investigation, waits for Biden’s invite to serve a second term, especially since Powell has \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-imposes-new-restrictions-on-officials-investment-activities-11634839207?mod=hp_lead_pos1\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efaced criticism\u003c/a\u003e from some Democratic lawmakers.—\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAh, the classic Econ 101 concepts: the invisible hand, the tragedy of the commons, the one about how if you stare into an orb you’ll receive free cryptocurrency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWorldcoin, a project cofounded by former Y Combinator president Sam Altman, is literally offering cryptocurrency (its own) in exchange for staring into a chrome orb that scans your irises. Yesterday it announced it’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.coindesk.com/business/2021/10/21/worldcoin-now-valued-at-1b-has-grand-plans-to-get-you-to-gaze-into-the-orb/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised $25 million\u003c/a\u003e, bringing its value to $1 billion. The concept is kind of a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/21/sam-altmans-worldcoin-wants-to-scan-your-eyes-in-exchange-for-crypto.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecrypto-attempt at universal basic income\u003c/a\u003e, and the eye-scanning orbs are—according to Worldcoin—a way to ensure that nobody gets multiple payouts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe use of biometric data has, of course, raised lots of privacy concerns. Critics \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/22557715/worldcoin-sam-altman-cryptocurency-orb-eye-scanning-iris-biometrics-privacy-concern?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edon’t buy into Worldcoin’s security claims\u003c/a\u003e, and others say the concept seems to require central control over the cryptocurrency—which doesn’t exactly jibe with blockchain decentralization principles. Worldcoin says it will never sell personal data (though it is currently \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.co.uk/article/worldcoin-cryptocurrency-sam-altman?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estoring it\u003c/a\u003e in order to, according to the company, improve fraud-detection algorithms).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot everyone is so skeptical, however. Worldcoin says 130,000 people have already gazed into the orb. The company plans to ramp up orb production from 30 to 4,000 per month beginning in November.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
